title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdos Problem #883: Cycles in the Coprime Graph**

This problem studies cycle structure in graphs defined by coprimality.

**Two Questions:**
1. Do all short odd cycles exist above a threshold? (Open)
2. Do tripartite subgraphs exist? (Solved by Sarkozy 1999)

The threshold floor(n/2) + floor(n/3) - floor(n/6) is tight.
mathContext: The problem connects number theory and extremal graph theory through coprimality conditions.

title: Coprime Graph Definition
content:
**coprimeGraph:**

The graph G(A) on vertex set A where two integers are adjacent iff they are coprime (gcd = 1).

**Definition:**
```lean
def coprimeGraph (A : Finset N) : SimpleGraph N where
  Adj := fun a b => a in A and b in A and a != b and Nat.Coprime a b
```

This is a sparse graph on integers with rich structure.

title: Threshold Value
content:
**threshold:**

The value floor(n/2) + floor(n/3) - floor(n/6).

By inclusion-exclusion, this counts integers <= n divisible by 2 or 3.

Asymptotically, threshold(n) approx (2/3)n.
mathContext: Arises from inclusion-exclusion on multiples of 2 and 3.

title: Extremal Set
content:
**extremalSet:**

The set of integers <= n divisible by 2 or 3.

This set has size exactly threshold(n) but contains no triangles in the coprime graph, since any two elements share a common factor.

This shows the threshold is tight.

title: Extremal Set is Triangle-Free
content:
**extremal_set_triangle_free:**

The extremal set (multiples of 2 or 3) has no triangles.

**Proof idea:** Any two elements in the set share either 2 or 3 as a common factor, so they cannot be coprime.

This proves the threshold is best possible.

title: Erdos-Sarkozy Theorem (1997)
content:
**erdos_sarkozy_odd_cycles:**

If |A| > threshold(n), then G(A) contains all odd cycles of length <= cn for some absolute constant c > 0.

This is a partial answer to Question 1.

**Reference:** Erdos-Sarkozy, "On cycles in the coprime graph of integers", Electron. J. Combin. (1997).
mathContext: The proof uses counting arguments and properties of coprime pairs.

title: Question 1 (Open)
content:
**erdos_883_question_1:**

Does |A| > threshold(n) imply G(A) contains all odd cycles of length <= n/3 + 1?

This asks for the specific constant 1/3, stronger than Erdos-Sarkozy.

**Status:** OPEN - the optimal constant is not known.

title: Complete (1,l,l) Tripartite Graph
content:
**hasTripartite:**

A (1,l,l) tripartite subgraph consists of:
- One central vertex v
- Two disjoint sets S and T, each of size l
- v is adjacent to every vertex in S and T

This is a star-like structure with 2l + 1 vertices.

title: Sarkozy's Theorem (1999)
content:
**sarkozy_tripartite:**

For large n, if |A| > threshold(n), then G(A) contains a complete (1,l,l) tripartite subgraph with l >> log n / log log n.

This solves Question 2 affirmatively.

**Reference:** Sarkozy, "Complete tripartite subgraphs in the coprime graph", Discrete Math. (1999).
mathContext: The l >> log n / log log n bound comes from estimates on coprime pairs.

title: Question 2 SOLVED
content:
**erdos_883_question_2_solved:**

For all n >= 1000 and A with |A| > threshold(n), the coprime graph G(A) contains a (1,l,l) tripartite subgraph.

This is the main solved part of Erdos #883.

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_883:**

The main theorem combines the solved parts:
- Question 2 is fully answered
- Question 1 has partial progress (cycles of length cn)

The tripartite subgraph result is the highlight.

title: Coprime Cycles
content:
**isCoprimeCycle:**

A coprime cycle is a sequence a_1, a_2, ..., a_k, a_1 where each consecutive pair is coprime.

Odd coprime cycles (k odd) are the focus of Question 1.

title: Triangles Above Threshold
content:
**triangles_above_threshold:**

For n >= 10 and |A| > threshold(n), the coprime graph G(A) contains a triangle.

This is the simplest case of odd cycle existence - the base of the cycle structure theory.

title: Threshold Formula
content:
**threshold_by_inclusion_exclusion:**

The threshold equals n/2 + n/3 - n/6 by definition.

This is the inclusion-exclusion formula: |mult of 2| + |mult of 3| - |mult of 6|.

title: Threshold Asymptotics
content:
**threshold_asymptotic:**

For n >= 6, threshold(n) <= 2n/3 + 1.

So the critical density is approximately 2/3 of the integers up to n.
